summary: This is an FBI Daily News Briefing summarizing news coverage from March 12, 2024, regarding Ghislaine Maxwell's appeal. Maxwell's lawyer argued before the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals that Jeffrey Epstein's 2007 Florida plea deal should protect Maxwell from prosecution, a claim challenged by prosecutors.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Imprisoned British socialite appealing her 2021 sex trafficking conviction and 20-year sentence. Her lawyer argued Epstein's 2007 plea deal should protect her.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: His 2007 non-prosecution agreement in Florida is the central legal issue in Maxwell's appeal. He died by suicide in 2019 while awaiting trial.

persons.name: Diana Fabi Samson
persons.context: Ghislaine Maxwell's lawyer who presented oral arguments before the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, claiming Epstein's plea deal protects Maxwell.

connections.description: Maxwell's prosecution is directly tied to Epstein's crimes. Her appeal hinges on the legal force of the non-prosecution deal Epstein secured.
Samson is Maxwell's defense attorney, representing her in the appeal before the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Non-Prosecution Deal
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein struck a non-prosecution agreement with a U.S. attorney in Florida to prevent a federal case against him.

events.title: Maxwell's Conviction
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell was convicted on sex trafficking charges and sentenced to 20 years in prison.

events.title: Maxwell's Appeal Hearing
events.description: Oral arguments were held before the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals regarding whether Epstein's 2007 plea deal protects Maxwell from prosecution.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide in a federal lockup while awaiting trial.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's lawyer argued before an appeals court that Jeffrey Epstein's 2007 Florida non-prosecution deal should invalidate Maxwell's 2021 conviction and sentence.
The central legal question is whether the agreement Epstein made with prosecutors in Florida also legally protected his associate, Ghislaine Maxwell, from prosecution in New York.
Maxwell is currently serving a 20-year sentence at a low-security federal prison in Tallahassee, Florida.
A similar legal argument about the force of Epstein's plea deal was raised by his lawyers after his 2019 arrest but became moot after his death.
The three-judge panel of the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals heard the arguments and reserved its decision.
